X-Yahoo-Profile: zenguyuno

From a recent Yahoo! science news article:

"Unexpectedly, the lemurs could remember sequences.
For instance, they showed they could remember the
order of appearance of random images by touching them
in order when they reappeared as a group."

I think that NEAT nets could be evolved that would
have the ability to remember, and then repeat back, a
series of random numbers.  (Of course, I may be
wrong.)

Animals in nature are called upon to do that all the
time.  For example, when a small mammal migrates to a
new territory, he needs to leave his nest, explore for
food while remembering his route.  Then, to return
home, he recalls the route in reverse.

Humans do it when they remember a new telephone number
for a short time.  Like when you say to someone:
Please dial 380-6637.  The person then dials the
number, perhaps never having heard it before.  Clearly
he had to memorize it and then recall it, even if it
is forgotten a few minutes later.

I think this is a worthwhile challenge for recurrent ANNs.

=====
Mitchell Timin
http://annevolve.sourceforge.net
